div.font:
A 40-year-old man presents for altered mental status. On arrival, he is actively hallucinating. He suddenly starts screaming, spitting, and kicking at staff. Attempts at verbal de-escalation fail. Further history and vitals cannot be obtained. In anticipation of giving chemical sedation, his chart is reviewed. It includes an ECG (shown) from a recent visit.
Which sedative agent is most likely to harm this patient?

a.title: Credit: Whitney Redline Sherman, MD, WellSpan York Hospital.

img.alt: Credit: Whitney Redline Sherman, MD, WellSpan York Hospital.

li.class: paper-shadow in multiple-response ng-scope ng-hide correct
paper-shadow in multiple-response ng-scope ng-hide active incorrect
paper-shadow in multiple-response ng-scope ng-hide incorrect
paper-shadow in multiple-response ng-scope ng-hide incorrect

input.div: You can drag/move image(s) to appropriate position to answer this question

div.font: Diphenhydramine is a first-generation antihistamine sometimes used in combination with antipsychotics to sedate agitated patients. In high doses (>1.0 g), diphenhydramine can cause prolongation of the QT interval and widening of the QRS complex due to sodium channel blockade. However, at normal doses, this is not generally a significant effect. Side effects are often attributed to anticholinergic properties and include dry mouth, tachycardia, urinary retention, blurred vision, and hallucinations or delirium.

Agitated and violent patients who fail verbal de-escalation attempts may require chemical and physical restraints with the goal of minimizing harm to the patient and staff in the emergency department. Although time constraints and limited history in these patients often preclude chart review prior to administering medication, chart review should be performed to guide the best therapy and avoid complications whenever possible. This patients ECG demonstrates a long QT interval. Any of the medications listed could be used for chemical sedation, but haloperidol has the highest risk of causing cardiac arrhythmias due to further prolongation of the QT interval and is most likely to cause harm.
Haloperidols association with QT prolongation, torsades de pointes, and sudden death is well described, and the risk of these cardiac complications increases when it is administered at higher than recommended doses or in intravenous (IV) form. Haloperidol is not approved by the FDA for IV administration, and the prescribing information recommends electrocardiographic monitoring if IV formulations are used. Patients with a known long QT interval should preferentially receive a sedation agent with a more favorable cardiac side effect profile than haloperidol, and caution should be used if the patient takes other medications known to prolong the QT interval or has other QT-prolonging conditions. Other antipsychotics known to increase the QT interval include thioridazine, mesoridazine, droperidol, ziprasidone, and quetiapine.

Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that is commonly used in combination with antipsychotics to sedate combative patients. Benzodiazepines do not prolong the QT interval and are a safe option for sedating patients with long QT intervals. Patients should be monitored for somnolence and respiratory depression following administration.

Ketamine is a noncompetitive antagonist of the N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor widely used as a dissociative anesthetic for sedation of acutely agitated patients in both prehospital and hospital settings. It has a good safety profile with only rare case reports of QT prolongation and is generally thought to be safe in patients with long QT intervals on ECG. More notable side effects of this medication include hypertension and tachycardia, laryngospasm, and emergence reactions. Ketamine can also exacerbate psychotic symptoms transiently in patients with schizophrenia, so careful consideration of the risks and benefits of this medication in patients with psychiatric disorders is recommended prior to use.

li.font: Haloperidol is associated with prolongation of the QT interval and requires electrocardiographic monitoring if administered intravenously or at high doses.
In patients with long QT intervals, safe chemical sedation options include ketamine, benzodiazepines, and diphenhydramine.

The risk and benefits of each sedative agent should be considered for specific patients prior to administration. When possible, ECGs should be reviewed to guide the best choice of medication and performed after administration to monitor for complications.
Singh TSS, Elahi F, Cheney B. Ketamine-induced QTc interval prolongation. J Anaesthesiol Clin Pharmacol. 2017 Jan-Mar;33(1):136-138.
